awd_titl_txt: AGS-PRF: Constraining and Modeling the Contribution of Organic Nitrate to Fine Mode Particulate Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
Organic nitrate is a major contributor to fine particular matter (PM2.5) that affects Earth’s radiative balance, visibility, and environmental and human health. Atmospheric formation pathways of this particulate organic nitrate are ill-defined, however. In the current project, data collected during past field campaigns will be synthesized and analyzed to determine particulate organic and inorganic nitrate concentrations in PM2.5. This data will be used to constrain formation mechanisms in current atmospheric chemistry models which will help guide future research, improve predictive modeling of PM2.5, and inform nitrogen budget models.

Data obtained with High-Resolution Time of Flight Aerosol Mass Spectrometers (HR-ToF-AMS) during 15 US field campaigns between 2009 and 2016 will be exploited for particulate organic and total nitrate. To test and validate mechanisms of organic and inorganic nitrate formation, temporally and spatially matched 3-D atmospheric chemistry transport (GEOS-Chem) model simulations will be performed and compared with observed concentrations. The new dataset will be made publicly available for use by other groups to guide future studies and help constrain regional and global models beyond the GEOS-Chem community. The PI will perform this work as a Postdoctoral Research Fellow at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology while engaging diverse undergraduate students in research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Fine particulate matter in the atmosphere, defined as particles with diameters below 2.5 μm (PM2.5) alter the radiative balance of the planet, degrade visibility, impact ecosystem health, and are a major public health concern. Thoroughly understanding sources of PM2.5, and correctly modeling its formation in global chemistry climate models is critical for designing effective air quality mitigation policies to reduce premature deaths related to air pollution and understand the total impact of future aerosol changes on climate. It has been extensively shown through direct observations that particulate nitrate is a major component of bulk PM2.5 mass on a global scale. Additionally, it has been widely predicted that particle nitrate will become an increasingly important component of bulk PM2.5 in the future, given continued global emission decreases in sulfate from emission control strategies, and concurrent increases in ammonia emissions from agriculture. However, these studies have historically focused on inorganic nitrate contributions to bulk PM2.5 mass, without considering organic nitrate and how it will respond to future changes in emissions, thereby resulting in an underestimation of the total impact of particle nitrate on air quality and climate. Ultimately, despite broad evidence that the organic nitrate component of total fine mode nitrate aerosol should be important to air quality  in the U.S, only 6 specific U.S. based field campaigns had reported observations  or organic nitrates in the U.S, in stark contrast to other regions like Europe, where an extensive effort to compile regional data was made. This work re-analyzed observations from 15 U.S field campaigns to extract a new regional set of observations of particle organic nitrate concentrations and utilized this data to wholistically evaluate how well a variety of chemical mechanisms, with modifications suggested by recent laboratory work, were able to predict particle phase organic nitrate concentrations to, ultimately, improve the formation and loss of organic nitrates in global models.  

Our results showed that the global chemical transport model, GEOS-Chem, underestimates the concentration of particle phase organic nitrates from nearly all campaigns that take place outside of the southeastern U.S. during summer. This is because the existing model mechanism was constrained using data exclusively from the southeastern U.S. in the summertime. This project showed a major disconnect in our ability to correctly model the formation and loss of particle organic nitrates in environments and emissions regimes different than the southeast summer, with important air quality implications for the recycling and permanent loss of nitrogen oxides (a major contributor to the formation of smog). However, variability in biogenic and anthropogenic emissions, transport, and deposition limited our ability to assess whether these model-measurement differences were due to chemical mechanism oversimplifications or poor representation of the other model processes that could influence the predicted concentrations of particle organic nitrates. Therefore, we preformed an extensive box modeling analysis utilizing the Framework for 0-D atmospheric modeling on all the ground-based campaigns where we constrained all measured chemical compounds to their observed values, thereby allowing us to investigate only the chemical mechanism?s fidelity, separate from obscuring influences like emissions, deposition, and transport.

This analysis provided firm evidence that GEOS-Chem?s chemical mechanism for the formation of particle phase organic nitrates was, indeed, underestimating their concentrations when compared to observations, particularly at night and in regions dominated by monoterpene emissions from evergreen plants rather than from isoprene emissions from deciduous plants, suggesting short comings in the model?s oxidation of monoterpenes from nighttime oxidation pathways. We tested a variety of mechanism improvements based on more explicit mechanisms and recent laboratory measurements and were able to improve the box model?s predictions of observed particle phase organic nitrate concentrations across the campaigns we analyzed. Results from this work are detailed in a publication currently in draft phase, that we plan to submit to a peer reviewed journal in the next 3 months.  This analysis gave us valuable insights into the broadscale representativeness of these laboratory experiments to the real atmosphere, which we used to create a new monoterpene oxidation chemical mechanism for GEOS-Chem. Results on how this new mechanism has changed GEOS-Chem?s ability to accurately predict particle organic nitrates are forth coming in a paper to be submitted in the next 6 months.

Several other products were created as part of this work, including publicly available tools to merge campaign datasets, compare GEOS-Chem output to campaign data, and automatically emulate any GEOS-Chem chemical mechanism within the Framework for 0-D atmospheric modelling. We anticipate these tools will be useful for comparing the fidelity of lumped chemical mechanisms to explicit mechanisms for a variety of other atmospheric chemistry questions and for generally making comparisons between GEOS-Chem and observational data, and plan to publish a model development paper describing these tools in the next 12 months.
